Decreases probability. Musk and similar elites can exert more effective influence through PACs, donations, and informal networks rather than building a new formal party infrastructure, especially given the high barriers and risks of formalization.

All recent reporting indicates Musk has reconciled with Trump, restored access, and shifted focus back to business and elite networking. The party threat was likely a bargaining device, never intended as a committed plan, and Musk’s actions since July (no filings, no organizing, no candidates, cooling rhetoric) confirm this. The base rate for such parties is exceedingly low, especially given the short remaining timeline and the high reputational and logistical costs. While last-minute volatility is always possible, the overwhelming likelihood is that the status quo persists and no FEC Form 1 is filed by Musk or his authentic proxies.

This lens is particularly relevant when assessing the likelihood of a disruptive figure like Elon Musk catalyzing a formal third-party effort within an established two-party system.
Sociology (Social Movement Theory).status_quo: No FEC Form 1 has been filed for an Elon Musk-founded political party; Musk is currently reconciled with Trump and the Republican Party, and has signaled a focus on business rather than third-party formation.

question_details.title: Will there be an FEC Form 1 filed for Elon Musk's Political Party before 2026?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-07-07 12:15:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/38822). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

Associated Press via NPR (July 6, 2025): [Musk forms new party after split with Trump over tax and spending bill](https://www.npr.org/2025/07/06/g-s1-76292/musk-political-party-america)

> Elon Musk said he's carrying out his threat to form a new political party after [his fissure with President Donald Trump](https://apnews.com/article/trump-musk-tax-bill-6e7845081259c34db785182c51569c0c), announcing the America Party in response to the president's sweeping tax cuts law.

> The formation of new political parties is not uncommon, but they typically struggle to pull any significant support away from the Republican and Democratic parties. But Musk, the world's richest man who spent at least \$250 million supporting Trump in the 2024 election, could impact the 2026 elections determining control of Congress if he is willing to spend significant amounts of money.

> It wasn't clear whether Musk had taken steps to formally create the new political party. Spokespeople for Musk and his political action committee, America PAC, didn't immediately comment Sunday.
> ‎
> As of Sunday morning, there were multiple political parties listed in the Federal Election Commission database that had been formed in the the hours since Musk's Saturday X post with versions of "America Party" of "DOGE" or "X" in the name, or Musk listed among people affiliated with the entity. But none appeared to be authentic, listing contacts for the organization as email addresses such as "wentsnowboarding \[at] yahoo.com″ or untraceable Protonmail addresses.

A purported Form 1 filing of the America Party on July 6, 2025 [was reported](https://x.com/elonmusk/status/1942009499109536185?s=46) by Elon Musk to be false. 

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":38822,"question_id":38143}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before January 1, 2026, a Form 1 "Statement of Organization" is filed with the US [Federal Election Commission](https://www.fec.gov/data/filings/?data_type=processed) for any Elon Musk-founded political party, such as the [America Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/America_Party).

Here are the relevant news articles:

**News briefs**
In a political development, Republicans achieved a significant victory by securing moderate Senate Democrats' support to end the longest government shutdown in U.S. history, though tensions are resurfacing over the expiration of Affordable Care Act tax credits on January 1, 2026, which could cause premium costs to surge. This comes amid electoral defeats driven by voter concerns over affordability, prompting emergency meetings in the West Wing. The White House has responded with a second reconciliation bill addressing both health care costs and Donald Trump’s contested tariff policies, currently under review by the Supreme Court. Meanwhile, a preliminary National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) report reveals that the left wing of a UPS cargo plane involved in a November 4, 2025, crash near Muhammad Ali International Airport in Louisville, Kentucky, had fatigue cracks and signs of overstress. The crash killed 14 people, including three crew members, and injured 23; the NTSB confirmed that the left engine and pylon detached during takeoff, with a 'repeating bell' heard seconds before impact. The investigation remains ongoing. In Ukraine, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy confirmed he has agreed to work on a U.S.-drafted peace plan aimed at ending Russia’s full-scale invasion, which has entered its fourth year. The 28-point proposal, modeled on the Gaza ceasefire, is being developed in coordination with U.S. officials, with Zelenskyy expected to discuss it with President Donald Trump soon. Finally, UNICEF reported that 417 million children in low- and middle-income countries face severe deprivation in education, health, and nutrition, with sub-Saharan Africa most affected, followed by South and East Asia and the Pacific. While progress has been made this century, funding cuts to development and humanitarian aid, along with climate change and conflict, threaten to reverse gains. Of these, 412 million children live on less than $3 per day, though this metric only captures part of the full scope of deprivation.

**Ossoff’s Billionaire Donors Expose Hypocrisy of Democratic Senator Criticizing Political Corruption**
Senator Jon Ossoff, a vulnerable Democratic candidate running for re-election in 2026, has publicly criticized the influence of corporate and billionaire money in U.S. politics, calling it the root cause of congressional failure to serve ordinary Americans. In a 2019 statement and on the left-leaning podcast 'Pod Save America,' Ossoff denounced the impact of 'rich political donors' and blamed the Citizens United decision for enabling secret, unlimited political spending. However, Federal Election Commission (FEC) records analyzed by Fox News Digital reveal that Ossoff has received nearly half a million dollars from billionaires since 2017, including over $154,000 in 2024 alone. Major contributors include Eric Schmidt, Reid Hoffman, James Cox-Chambers, Henry Laufer, and members of the Soros family. Despite claiming to reject PAC corporate money, Open Secrets data shows significant contributions from individuals linked to Google, Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, and Meta. Additionally, Ossoff received thousands from PACs representing law firms, lobbying groups, agribusiness, and unions. His campaign claims to be driven by small donors—averaging $36 from about 233,000 contributors—but over 80% of funds came from outside Georgia, with top donors from California, New York, and the D.C.-Virginia area. Ossoff declined to respond to inquiries about the discrepancy. He is described by CNN as the 'most threatened Democratic senator' and has positioned himself as a champion of a 'popular coalition' despite accepting substantial support from wealthy donors, including Illinois Governor JB Pritzker, whose net worth exceeds $3.5 billion. Ossoff narrowly defeated Republican David Perdue in a 2020 runoff election and now faces re-election in a state Trump won in 2024 by a two-point margin.

**Elon Musk Reunites With Donald Trump After Month, Makes Official Appearance At U.S. State Dinner**
Elon Musk made his first public appearance at a U.S. State Dinner at the White House on November 20, 2025, marking a significant reconciliation with Donald Trump after a period of public conflict. The two were seen interacting warmly, with Musk receiving a pat on the stomach upon arrival, signaling a restored relationship. Their rift began in June 2025 when Musk criticized Trump’s 'One Big Beautiful Bill' on X, calling it 'utterly insane' and 'destructive in nature,' citing its potential to destroy millions of jobs and harm future industries. Trump retaliated by threatening to withdraw federal funding from Musk’s companies. Musk further escalated tensions by referencing the Jeffrey Epstein files and announcing plans to form a third political party in July 2025, which could have harmed the Republican base. The first sign of reconciliation occurred at the funeral of assassinated activist Charlie Kirk, where they were photographed in a friendly exchange. The White House later released a monochrome image of the two, suggesting their reunion was intentional. Musk had previously been invited to a White House AI summit hosted by Melania Trump in the renovated Rose Garden, where he clarified he could not attend but sent a representative. At the State Dinner, Musk, dressed in formal attire, engaged with Trump and other dignitaries, including posing for a selfie with football legend Cristiano Ronaldo. The event went viral, sparking speculation about the political and technological implications of their renewed alliance.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 20, 2025 04:14 PM
Source:[The Inquisitr](https://www.inquisitr.com/elon-musk-reunites-with-donald-trump-after-month-makes-official-appearance-at-u-s-state-dinner)

**Tesla CEO Elon Musk does exactly what US President Donald Trump asked him to do on stage - The Times of India**
On November 20, 2025, Tesla CEO Elon Musk publicly responded to a humorous on-stage request by former U.S. President Donald Trump during a high-profile White House dinner and U.S.-Saudi Investment Forum. Trump, hosting Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, jokingly asked the audience if Musk had 'ever thanked me for that properly?' In response, Musk posted on X (formerly Twitter): 'I would like to thank President Trump for all he has done for America and the world.' Trump had previously praised Musk multiple times during the forum, particularly highlighting federal tax deductions that benefit domestic car production, and remarked, 'You are so lucky I'm with you, Elon,' referencing policies that have supported Musk’s ventures. The public reconciliation followed a bitter feud earlier in 2025, when Musk criticized Trump’s tax and spending plans and announced plans to form a new political party, prompting Trump to threaten to withdraw billions in federal subsidies. The two men had previously worked closely, with Musk backing Trump’s 2024 election campaign and briefly leading the Department of Government Efficiency, overseeing federal cost-cutting initiatives. A video from the event showed Trump, Melania Trump, and the Crown Prince spotting Musk and gently tapping him, to which Musk responded with a nod.

**Trump, Elon Musk bromance back on: Inside how the president, mogul ended their nasty feud**
A significant thaw in the relationship between former President Donald Trump and Elon Musk has occurred, marked by public displays of camaraderie such as Trump's three shout-outs to Musk during a speech before Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and a warm arm-tap at a White House banquet. This reconciliation follows a bitter feud that erupted after Musk criticized Trump’s 2024 One Big Beautiful Bill Act, which included tax cuts and other campaign promises, and later threatened to form a third party, the America Party, on July 5, 2025. The détente was facilitated by Vice President JD Vance and White House Chief of Staff Susie Wiles, who served as trusted intermediaries, according to five sources close to the White House. These sources emphasized that Musk values private, candid communication with Vance and Wiles, who have helped restore trust. Musk’s support was further solidified by his $290 million in donations to Republican campaigns in 2024 and his role as unpaid head of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) from January to May 2025, which Wiles praised as impactful. The reconciliation began with a private conversation at the September 21, 2025, funeral of Charlie Kirk, Turning Point USA cofounder, and was reinforced by Musk’s renewed public support for the administration. Fiskback's company, Fiskback Investment, had temporarily halted trading of a Tesla-related investment fund due to Musk's re-entry into politics, but resumed it later. 'It's been 17 days since he said he would create the party... there's no file, no candidate, no nothing significant', Fiskback said. The tension between Trump and his former ally has eased, with Trump posting on social media 'I want Elon, and all companies in our country, to thrive, to thrive like never before'. However, the Democratic National Committee, which Musk used to spend around $250 million on in the 2024 election, remains active. The committee's purchasing power, a key electoral tool, remains intact despite not filing any reports this year, putting it at risk of non-compliance with Federal Election Commission rules. Ives believes Musk will continue to spend his money on supporting his preferred candidates, but it won't be a major draw for Musk or his efforts, unlike running a third party.

summary: Across all expert perspectives—including elections administration, law, political science, political consulting, and sociology—there is overwhelming consensus that it is highly unlikely an authentic FEC Form 1 will be filed for an Elon Musk-founded political party before January 1, 2026. The primary reasoning centers on Musk's high-profile reconciliation with Donald Trump and the Republican establishment, which has removed his core incentive for formal party creation. Experts note that, historically, most billionaire or celebrity threats to found new parties in the U.S. do not result in official FEC registration, especially when the underlying elite or policy conflict is resolved. Although Musk is known for unpredictable moves and possesses the resources and organizational capacity for rapid action, all recent reporting indicates that party plans have been shelved, and no genuine filing activity has been detected in FEC records. The time remaining until the deadline is short—about five weeks—and the procedural and reputational costs to filing now outweigh any strategic advantage, given Musk's restored access and influence within the GOP. There is some minor allowance for a last-minute surprise due to Musk’s volatility, but such a scenario would require a dramatic, currently unforeseen rupture with Trump or the Republican Party. As such, the predicted probabilities by the experts are consistently low, generally in the 2-5% range, with a strong expectation that no valid Form 1 will be filed with Musk as founder or co-founder before January 1, 2026.
